title: Remove inappropriate "references" words in go faqs.
body:
### What did you expect to see?

The meaning of the word "reference" in Golang is totally different from other languages.
In Golang, "reference" means a pointer referring another value.
There is no reference values in Golang (if pointers are not viewed as reference values).

In the faq, maps, slices, and channels references are viewed as reference values (https://golang.org/doc/faq#references), this is inappropriate and will make many confusions in the process of learning Go.

In fact, maps, slices, and channels (and function values) are all wrappers of pointers. They are just normal internal struct values.

I proposal to replace the question "why are maps, slices, and channels references while arrays are values" with an appropriate one, which will explain the internal structure of maps, slices, and channels. 

Remove the "reference value" concept is good to unify the definitions and make the docs clear.

### What did you see instead?

There are 4 occurrences of "references", 3 of them are inappropriate.
